title: David Walliams earns '£50,000 an episode' for ITV flop The Nightly Show despite falling viewing figures
text:

Viewing figures fell dramatically after the first time it aired, but The Nightly Show host's salary hasn't. 
David Walliams is reportedly earning £50,000 an episode for the ITV flop, meaning he'll have raked in £250,000 by the end of this week. 
If that number's right, it means David will earn a whopping £2,083 per minute and £34 per second. 
The Britain's Got Talent judge is earning the big bucks for the show, according to The Sun. 
But the chat show has been panned by critics and the public, who tuned out on mass after the first episode. Read More Chaos as ITV's The Nightly Show loses HALF of its viewers already - but bosses insist they're sticking with it It means he could earn £250,000 this week (Photo: Rex Features) 
An impressive 3.7 million tuned in the the show's first offering at 10pm on Monday, but just 1.36 million decided to watch on Tuesday. 
The Little Britain funnyman, 45, is just the first in a number of celebs lined up to host the show in the coming weeks. 
Gordon Ramsay, Davina McCall and Mel and Sue have all been drafted in take the helm during the eight-week run, which saw the broadcaster's nightly news moved back half an hour to 10.30pm. 
The hope was also that the Nightly Show could bring in younger viewers to sell advertising but to make matters worse it had just 76,000 16-24 year-olds. 
However despite all this, one show insider was staying upbeat and told Square Eyes: “Whilst there is room for improvement, there is definitely still a feeling that we can turn this ship around. He's one of a number of hosts lined up (Photo: ITV) 
“Judging it two shows into an eight week run is a little harsh and we are excited about lots of the other hosts coming up – it will be a very different show next week with John Bishop . 
"John is even coming onto Friday’s show for a handover along with The Voice hosts. 
“We are also working on getting some big name guests, we knew the audience was always going to fluctuate on a new show like this.” Read More The news isn't good for the Nightly crew - but it DID pull in 2.9million viewers on its first night David had Martin Clunes as a guest (Photo: Rex Features) 
ITV boss Kevin Lygo insisted at the start of the week he would wait until the end of the eight week run before deciding if the Nightly Show could become a constant presence in the schedules. 
You wouldnt bet on it at this stage. 
But an ITV exec told us: “No one was screaming with delight after the great ratings on day one and there are no screams of despair when the figures dropped. We are trying something different here and it is still early days.”
